The airport is located on the Changi neighborhood at Singapore's east coast, about 25 km from the downtown area. Due to the small size of the country, all flights from the airport are international, and there are no domestic flights.

The airport is one of the world's busiest, and also the world's best! Airlines have merrily filled in slots to fly to Changi as the government swiftly expands the airport. Passengers are also made home with facilities more than what one would expect at an ordinary airport. Gardens & artworks fill the airside to sooth the eyes, a massage parlor & spa to relax the muscles, a swimming pool at Terminal 1 to keep the body fit, and a cinema & television screens to entertain the heart. The airport has been alive primarily because of the inception and expansion of Singapore's flag carrier, Singapore Airlines, and its little subsidiary sister, SilkAir. Low cost carriers have also filled in slots to fly passengers to other countries in Asia, primarily to Singapore's neighbors, Indonesia and Malaysia.

The airport began its operation in 1981, before that all civilian traffic has shifted through 3 airports across Singapore for the past 50 years: Paya Lebar from 1955, Kallang from 1937, and Seletar from 1930. The need for expansion was urgent at that time, but at the same time was hindered with the surrounding urban growth, which makes airport expansion impossible for the long term. Thus, the government of Singapore decided to pick a spot at Changi in the east coast, and do land reclamation should there be a need for expansion. Up to now, the airport has been growing & expansion has been still remarkably easy.

Changi houses 3 terminals: Terminal 1, 2, and 3. Most airlines, especially low cost carriers, use Terminal 1, and a few more at Terminals 2 & 3. Keep in mind that Singapore Airlines departs from either Terminal 2 or 3, depending on where you are flying to.

Fortunately transfers are quite easy, all terminals are connected with a free Skytrain service from 4 AM to 1.30 AM, without passing through immigration. Terminal 1 is physically connected to Terminals 2 and 3, and you will not notice you're in a different terminal except by reading the signs. When you return to the airport and are flying Singapore Airlines, be sure to at least tell the driver your destination so he knows which terminal to take you to.

Unlike most other airports, there are no separate zones for departing and arriving passengers in the main terminals before passport control, hence arriving passengers are free to shop and eat at the airside if they are not in a hurry. In addition, if they don't have checked luggage, they can clear passport control at any terminals.
From the airport there are a number of ways to get into the city:

A Ground Transport Desk is available at all terminals (Arrival Hall) and will arrange you a shuttle. The shuttle costs $9 per adult and $6 per child (aged 12 years and above) and will take you to most downtown hotels. 

A coach service to Kotabaru II Terminal, Johor Bahru, Malaysia (to Larkin Terminal from August 1, 2014) has been launched by the Transtar Cross Border Service. Fares are $7 (cash only!). The first bus departs at 8.15 AM and the last leaves at 11.15 PM.

Changi Airport is connected to the East-West line of the MRT. The MRT station is located between Terminals 2 and 3, and is well indicated from Terminal 1. When going to the city, you'll need to change trains at Tanah Merah – exit on the

door and cross the platform. When going to the airport, just cross to the middle platform. The 30-minute ride to City Hall station costs $1.90 plus a refundable $1 deposit. Trains run from 05:31 to 23:18.

All three terminals are well-connected by the SkyTrain, an automatic driverless people mover, that operates from 04.00 to 01.30. When the train is not in operation, you must walk. A walk from Terminal 2 to Terminal 3 or vice-versa should take about 30 minutes as you have to pass through Terminal 1. A buggy car that will take you to your boarding gate, very useful if you are in a hurry, is available upon request.

Even if you are stuck in the airport, there are plenty of ways to kill time, as each terminal has a unique design and the airside areas of T1, T2, and T3 are attractions in themselves. T2, arguably the most interesting, has an indoor garden, a music listening area with couches and mood lighting, a computer gaming room, a small cinema (you can bring your luggage trolleys inside and park them at the back), paid massage services and, of course, plenty of duty-free shops. T3, the newest, has a butterfly garden and plenty of natural light, but fewer entertainment options. T1 has a swimming pool for $13.91 and jacuzzi, both open until 23:00. There is an outdoor cactus garden on the roof of T1. You can travel between the main terminals without passing through immigration and, if you have no checked-in luggage to collect, you can clear passport control and customs at any terminal.

ATMs abound and money changers offer reasonable rates as well, although you pay a small premium compared to the city.

Shops are extremely varied and, if removed to more than 100 countries, would constitute their largest mall! All accept American Express, VISA and MasterCard; most accept Diners Club, JCB and UnionPay.

If you're just arriving and need to buy a SIM card for your phone, there are plenty of tourist help-oriented shops that will be happy to sell you one with $50-$70 of credit on it (and that's how much it will cost). 1GB of data for a week is only $7 though, so if you're only in Singapore for a short time, the bigger cards are definitely overkill. Instead, head to the money changers - you can buy a $15 SIM card there.

Singapore has very strict drug laws, and
drug trafficking carries a mandatory death penalty
— which is also applied to foreigners. Even if you technically haven't entered Singapore and are merely

(i.e. changing flights without the need to clear passport control and customs) while in possession of drugs, you would still be subject to capital punishment. The paranoid might also like to note that in Singapore, it is an offence even to have any drug metabolites in your system, even if they were consumed outside Singapore, and Customs occasionally does spot urine tests at the airport! In addition, bringing in explosives or firearms without a permit is also a capital offence in Singapore.

By and large, the airport is safe as security officers frequently patrol by segways & buggy cars and the building is well-lit throughout the day. You will see at least some people wherever you step in at, fewer at the gates. Use practical common sense by not going to dark places. Report any unattended bags to the security officers.
